text:
Not sure which channel is most appropriate for this, but does anyone have any favorite resources for setting up advanced filtering in a blog or otherwise? 

For some context: After toying with about a billion different options for a real estate property listing page for a client, I think I’ve determined that setting it up as a blog and utilizing advanced category filters is the way to go (if anyone has any different ideas please feel free to share), but I haven’t found many resources on how to implement something like that. Ideally people would be able to filter by at least 3 different categories. 

Any thoughts?

Not trying to spam, just floating this back to the top of the chat as there was a Chicago HubSpot Dev event last night, where I presented the extension. Atleast a handful of people were not on the HS dev slack and were going to get invited. just sharing this post so those people don’t have to scroll back through posts to find it.
The best trick i have is to use the blog topic functionality

so since it’s a real estate listing you could make topics for all of the features of a house.

Just prefix them so you can differentiate them from your normal blog topics.

So an example `x_bedrooms_4`

then in your hubl you can grab all of a blog’s topics - then find specific ones like bedrooms and use the hubl cut filter to cut out the `x_bedrooms_` part when you want to display the value.

The advantage with using topics is, then you will be able to do related listings and whatnot
<@U24PLTUJD> We like using mixitup by Kunka Labs.
No worries Jon. Thanks for being active in the HubSpot Dev community and speaking at the event (and sharing the chrome extension)! Together were building a strong community :raised_hands:

Is there a way to do, in an email template, something like> “if transactional email” to check if the email type is transactional vs. another subscription type? Or “if subscription type ==” and then some logic?

Hey just noticed as of 30 minutes ago a site I was working on stopped loading a javascript file that was previously loaded on it. the template had no revisions, the javascript file had no revisions the page itself didn’t have revisions removing the javascript. 

We didn’t build the page initially another dev did. We suspect their JS file was loaded through content settings in the site footer.
And we think this because weirdly the site footer html was empty, and normally our team has tracking codes and stuff in there
Sounds a little sketch
Did it get overridden by changing the footer on one of the domains from the dropdown?
i ha dan issue where all of the navigation items were downloading the page instead of navigating
*overwritten*
I’m kinda leaning towards the thought that it might have gotten overwritten on accident but there’s no way to check that theory there’s no revision history there
I use this
<http://kapilkashyap.github.io/jquery-filter-json-plugin/>
and I load all the blogs into it using hubl in the beginning of page load and create a javscript object of them, then on page load they show up
<https://www.gliffy.com/blog>
that is an example. I think something like mixitup may be easier to implement though.
I had a similar issue with renaming an image folder. All images wipe out unless we return the folder to the same name as it was.

We recently switched a client to HubSpot and we are not able to setup a redirect with for the following URL: <https://mysite.com>. Whenever we try, the "https" is changed to "http", but the client is having errors only when visitors attempt to visit the SSL domain. Is there a way to setup this redirect? has anyone else encountered this issue and been able to setup the redirect?

Most articles I've encountered state we need to add the following to our .htaccess file but that is not something we can change ourselves in HS right?
'RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{HTTPS} off
RewriteRule (.*) https://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [R=301,L]'
